awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Drainage network evolution following continental glaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
When the Pleistocene ice sheets retreated from low-elevation continental interiors (for example, the upper Midwest), they left behind vast low-relief plains dotted with wetland basins and few well-established streams. It is evident from looking at landscapes formed on glaciated plains of different ages that elaborate stream networks become established over time, reducing the abundance and extent of wetlands and increasing the extent of streams. However, the rate and mechanism of this "drainage integration" is unknown. The consequences of drainage integration are significant not only because erosional reshaping modifies the physical landscape, but also because it forges faster and more direct hydrological connections between uplands and streams. These hydrological connections have important implications for water resource management throughout these landscapes.

This collaborative project will combine laboratory simulations, computer modeling of landscape evolution, and field and geospatial analysis of stream network evolution in real Midwestern landscapes uncovered by Pleistocene ice sheets at different times in the last ice age. Each effort will be aimed at understanding the processes and rates of channel extension and wetland basin breaching in real and simulated landscapes. The key objectives are to identify how natural processes of water flow and sediment transport in these settings govern the spatial patterns of evolving stream networks and their rate of development through time.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Our goal was to better understand the processes and spatial patterns of drainage network expansion in low-relief landscapes following continental glaciation.  We have documented drainage capture events using field observations of topography, sedimentology and soils; quantified the rates of drainage network expansion and non-contributing area loss using geospatial analysis; identified morphological signatures of channel head propagation assisted by groundwater using physical experiments; and characterized channel network and long-profile forms influenced by groundwater contributions using physical and numerical models. 


We produced a new map of landform regions spanning the glaciated Midwest that harmonizes information collected by individual states and counties. We documented pre-agriculture steam networks and compared them with deglaciation times to determine that stream networks in this region can reach their fully mature extent within 50,000 years of evolution.  Numerical modeling of stream network expansion suggests that water must move across subtle watershed boundaries, either in the subsurface or by filling and spilling of lakes, to allow for the rates of evolution required.  Numerical models indicate that significant groundwater contribution to rivers produces stream profile shapes and landforms near the channel head that are recognizable and distinct from these features in the absence of groundwater contributions.  Physical experiments yielded complementary results with distinct changes in channel morphology associated with differences in the permeability and cohesiveness of sediments. 


This project will have several key impacts on geomorphology. First, we establish that drainage networks are likely reestablished during each interglacial episode. This rate of recovery is unexpectedly rapid, and our physical and numerical models suggest that water transfer across surface water divides, either through groundwater flow across divides or via lakes filling and spilling, is likely necessary to drive such rapid evolution.  This finding reverses causality in previous conceptual models of drainage network growth.  Previous work focused on how channel expansion captured drainage area and rerouted flow. Our work suggests a conceptual model in which surface and subsurface routing of flow, initially decoupled from incised channels on the surface, drives headward growth of channel networks with capture of surficial drainage area occurring in response to routing. This new conceptual model will drive future field investigations to consider new mechanisms of growth and suggests characterization of the spatial heterogeneity of permeability is particularly important for understanding network growth in this region.  In addition to this change in paradigm for channel network growth, we also identify morphological signatures in drainage patterns, river long profiles and channel heads that are associated with a substantial contribution of groundwater to fluvial evolution, providing targets for future geospatial and field mapping activities. 


This cross-disciplinary project promises to lead to as many as seven peer-reviewed publications, each involving at least one student author. Ten students were afforded research experience under this award, and these included five women and two from groups under-represented in STEM fields (Latina, African-American). We sincerely hope that these research experiences will embolden these students to pursue additional advanced learning and thus improve representation in the STEM workforce. Curriculum was developed for a senior-undergraduate level course in Geomorphology at the University of Illinois based on drainage density mapping and relationships between rivers and glacial moraines in East-central Illinois, and will be shared with the geoscience education community through the Science Education Resource Center.
